import React from "react"; import Top from './Top'; function CaseJC(props) { return (
Jason Clerk Industrial Design
  • Client: Jason Clerk
  • Timing: 2021
  • Duration: 6 Months
  • My Role: Designer {"&"} Developer
The Backstory

Jason Clerk is a Toronto-based Industrial Designer with a career spanning 20+ years, designing goods across a wide variety of categories. Jason contacted me to inquire about building a website where clients and potential employers could go to see his work online. Visit Jason{"’"}s Website.

Level Up

Being the first site that I designed and built entirely from scratch, I had three key takeaways from the experience:

Time Management - I now have a better sense of how much time is needed to complete various design-related tasks. I also learned what areas to focus on to improve my speed, and what tasks I can accomplish quickly/with ease.

Presenting a Rationale - I learned the value of being able to clearly articulate a rationale for a design decision and how to effectively present that rationale with supporting evidence to ensure stakeholders are confident moving forward.

Trusting My Instincts - At times my intuition would signal that I was not confident in some aspect of my design. I learned to listen to this signal and seek feedback from users, do more research, check with more experienced designers or to keep iterating if I was seeing progress.

Problem to Solve {"&"} Core Considerations

  • - Jason needed a professional website that would quickly communicate his body of work and process to clients and potential employers
  • - He wanted a clean, simple, sporty design
  • - There were limitations with his product photography, being mostly low resolution

Path to Solution
{/*
Path to Solution

Each phase of my design process articulated below involved reviewing progress with Jason, collecting feedback, and incorporating the feedback into the design. Additionally, prior to finalizing the design, Jason shared visuals with a few peers (also Industrial Designers) to collect their feedback on the design.

Research {"&"} Inspiration

  • - Referenced other portfolio sites
  • - Sourced visual inspiration (packaging design, other sites, etc.)
  • - Identified inital patterns for content organization/grouping

Personas {"&"} Use Cases

Outlined personas, defined user needs and explored the following priorities visually through preliminary sketches:

  • - Jason{"'"}s full suite of products needed to be visible to users from the moment they landed on his site
  • - Users needed to be able to easily drill down to discover more info about each product and Jason{"’"}s process
  • - Jason{"’"}s contact info needed to be quick and easy to find

Ideation {"&"} Iterative Sketching

  • - Produced lots of fast rough sketches
  • - Experimented with how to organize the content and navigation based on user flow(s) from previous step

Concept Development

  • - Looking at the core considerations outlined above, narrowed down to 4-5 sketches from ideation stage to explore further.
  • - Created a few quick mock ups to determine the aesthetic direction (presented to Jason to get his feedback)

Low/Medium Wireframing

  • - Jason liked elements from multiple concepts, so I cherry-picked those elements and combined them into 1 version to pursue further.
  • - Assembled low-fi and eventually medium-fi wireframes to nail down layout and find cohesion between the various product images.

Final Design

  • - Established colour palette, type styles, states, and sourced UI elements to arrive at final design in high-fidelity wireframes.
  • - Received approval on the final design, developed the site using HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, React and then deployed via GitHub pages.

*/}
Outcomes

Jason now had an online destination that he could direct clients/employers towards to view his work that was up to date with current standards. Within a few days of launching the site, Jason was able to use it as a tool in phone calls with clients to show/discuss work. This allowed Jason to advance the process of working with a new client and allowed for more meaningful discussions.

Next Steps

  • - Collect, consolidate and incorporate user feedback to improve the usability of the site design
  • - Incorporate changes to carousels/pagination/navigation based on feedback collected from a UX Design mentor
  • - Work with Jason to add new projects to his website and update his profile photo

{/*
Level Up

Being the first site that I designed and built entirely from scratch, I had three key takeaways from the experience:

Time Management - I now have a better sense of how much time is needed to complete various design-related tasks. I also learned what areas to focus on to improve my speed, and what tasks I can accomplish quickly/with ease.

Presenting a rationale - I learned the value of being able to clearly articulate a rationale for a design decision and how to effectively present that rationale with supporting evidence to ensure stakeholders are confident moving forward.

Trusting my gut - Over the course of this project, I learned to trust my gut. My intuition became a signal that I might not be confident in some aspect of my design, and as a result I knew to seek feedback from users, do more research, or check with more experienced designers. Alternatively, my gut at times told me to keep iterating, particularly if I was seeing progress (albeit slow) because eventually I would arrive at a successful solution. By learning to listen to my intuition my overall design process improved tremendously.

*/}
); } export default CaseJC;
